review I love Bujold's full-fleshed, incredibly human characters. I relish the adventures they encounter. I love her introspective musings on the nature of h I love Bujold's full-fleshed, incredibly human characters. I relish the adventures they encounter. I love her introspective musings on the nature of honor, mercy, humanity and society. I LOVE THESE BOOKS! Shards and Cordelia's Honor are character-driven, action-packed, humane and romantic without mush. Warrior's Apprentice actually takes both character-development and action/adventure and steps them up--to an insanely addictive level. More please! ...more

review One of the things I love about Bujold's books is the way she has created widely different, intricately crafted societies in her world. Cetaganda's cas One of the things I love about Bujold's books is the way she has created widely different, intricately crafted societies in her world. Cetaganda's caste system is as formal and mannered as the medieval Japan, and similarly compelling. As a plus, the ever-entertaining Miles plays detective and diplomat. ...more
review OK, it's not quite as awesome as Shards of Honor, but it's still really excellent. Have I mentioned that I LOVE these characters?
review The beginning is a bit Peter-Parker syndrome-ish, but once it gets rolling... WOW! I just couldn't stop chortling over Miles...

review I really enjoyed this, in the same way that I enjoyed Cryptonomicon a decade ago. The tech-world of T'Rain is intriguing and enticingly developed, and I really enjoyed this, in the same way that I enjoyed Cryptonomicon a decade ago. The tech-world of T'Rain is intriguing and enticingly developed, and the action is enjoyably non-stop. Actually, the action was a bit too non-stop for my taste; by the last hundred pages, I was sort of thinking "running...blah blah blah...bang-bang...blah...bang...OK, let's wrap it up." ...more

review I don't usually have the patience for short stories: by the time the characters and story have blossomed in my head, the narrative is done, and I feel I don't usually have the patience for short stories: by the time the characters and story have blossomed in my head, the narrative is done, and I feel cheated. These are an exception. Connie Willis is such a fabulous writer. Her stories are humane, humorous and bursting with imagination. It's a delight to turn them in ones mind after reading. ...more

review The premise was great, and it was certainly hard to put down--until the author started going overboard on exposing the back-story of each character. A The premise was great, and it was certainly hard to put down--until the author started going overboard on exposing the back-story of each character. At the same time, despite the melodramatic back-stories, the characters seem more like archetypes than real characters: the Egotistical Actor, the Heroic Yet Traumatized Soldier, the Saintly Woman Wronged. The dialogue seemed forced. Certain stereotypes about Muslim terrorists, the over-sexed French and emotionally frigid scientists also rubbed me the wrong way, and (as so often) I have a few nits to pick with the historical details. The conclusion felt more like an exercise in narrative structure variation than a satisfying and believable course of events. All the same, it was better written than much of what's available, and I did enjoy reading it. ...more

review A fun, slightly fluffy classic sci-fi adventure split between time travelers from the future who are visiting the Crash of the Hindenburg (except it d A fun, slightly fluffy classic sci-fi adventure split between time travelers from the future who are visiting the Crash of the Hindenburg (except it doesn't), a NASA scientist in the late 1990s and his alternate-timeline self. Fun, fun, fun and more than a little tongue in cheek. I love the idea that the perfect way for time travelers to hide among us is to disguise their ships as classic flying saucer UFOs. It's even more insidious than using 1950s British police boxes. ...more

review Good, rollicking fun steampunk adventure set in a tiny made-up European kingdom off the coast of Ireland at the turn of the last century. Swordplay! I Good, rollicking fun steampunk adventure set in a tiny made-up European kingdom off the coast of Ireland at the turn of the last century. Swordplay! Invention! Romance! Betrayal! Wrongful imprisonment! Glowing coral! Diamond mines! Balloon flight! Castles! Explosions! It's like the Count of Monte Cristo meets the Wright Brothers and the Hardy Boys--less of that worldly continental bitterness but plenty of swashbuckling derring-do. I highly recommend this for geeksters craving adventure and adventurers in need of sci-fi. ...more
review (3.8) A cute, coy perspective on trendsetters and fads, mixed up with some geekiness, a bit of mystery, and plenty of wit. Fun.

review At first, I started out enjoying this novel quite a bit. The pacing is brisk, not to say a little frantic (think sleep-deprived medical staff), and I At first, I started out enjoying this novel quite a bit. The pacing is brisk, not to say a little frantic (think sleep-deprived medical staff), and I liked the characters, who were well-fleshed out. Then... I don't think it counts as a spoiler to say that the ending ruined this for me. In addition to feeling cheated by what appeared a desperate attempt to end the book at any price, I resented the sacrifice of a good build-up to what seemed to me a cheap metaphor. Hmmph. ...more

review Don't start this unless you have access to book 2: All Clear. Yes, it's FAT, but the pacing is so fast, the setting so compellingly conveyed, the char Don't start this unless you have access to book 2: All Clear. Yes, it's FAT, but the pacing is so fast, the setting so compellingly conveyed, the characters so well-developed, that I ripped through both books in no time. Connie Willis feelingly portrays the gorgeous day-to-day heroism of Britons on the homefront during the Blitz, and the "unintended consequences of time-travel" conceit allows readers to increasingly appreciate just how narrowly the Battle of Britain was won. I loved To Say Nothing of the Dog and Doomsday Book, but this is Willis' magnum opus. The reader on the audiobook is extraordinarily talented, and I highly recommend that for both volumes. ...more

review (3.5) Although it was well crafted, I was rather disappointed that this book didn't rock my world after all the great things I'd heard about it. The m (3.5) Although it was well crafted, I was rather disappointed that this book didn't rock my world after all the great things I'd heard about it. The main character wasn't very well developed and didn't seem to have much agency, which diminished the tension of a storyline that felt, to me, a little too artificially smooth. Certainly worth reading, but I've enjoyed other books by this author more. ...more

review I really like this take on vampirism: from a public health, parasitology perspective. The setting is modern, gritty Manhattan, and instead of gorgeous I really like this take on vampirism: from a public health, parasitology perspective. The setting is modern, gritty Manhattan, and instead of gorgeously gothic villains, the creatures he deals with are insane, sewer-dwelling young adults, disease spreading rats, and an army of ancient... bureaucrats. The bizarre-but-true parasite tidbits sprinkled throughout the text make Westerfeld's model of "peeps" all that much more compelling and believable, as do the realistic and sympathetic main characters. Probably my favorite vampire book of the year. ...more

Compelling. ...more

review In describing this book, it's hard to steer away from thinking of it as sort of A Handmaid's Tale for kids. Among The Hidden is a well-paced and skill In describing this book, it's hard to steer away from thinking of it as sort of A Handmaid's Tale for kids. Among The Hidden is a well-paced and skillfully crafted story about the third son born into a family in a country where each woman is only permitted two children. Luke's actions and emotions are intensely realistic, and the totalitarian regime in which he lives is all too believable. Extra kudos to Haddix for getting kids to think about issues of population control, resource distribution, agency and freedom. ...more

review This is a hard book to rate. At points, it is pure genius. Foster Wallace's satire of addiction, consumerism and entertainment is intoxicating. At the This is a hard book to rate. At points, it is pure genius. Foster Wallace's satire of addiction, consumerism and entertainment is intoxicating. At the same time, I was incredibly frustrated by the utter absence of resolution and the lack of structure. I spent years looking for someone else who's finished the tome to discuss it with me; it's the sort of book that requires discussion. Unfortunately, no one else seems willing to delve through the 1100+ pages for the sake of a chat. ...more
